content.text: Once upon a time, in a cozy little cottage at the edge of a green forest, there lived an old woman and her husband. They were kind and gentle, but they had no children to keep them company, and
they often felt lonely. One morning, the old woman decided to bake a gingerbread man to cheer herself up. She mixed the dough with flour, sugar, ginger, and cinnamon, rolled it out flat,
and cut it into the shape of a little man. Then she added two raisins for eyes, a cherry for a mouth, and three small buttons down his front. Finally, she placed him in the oven to bake.
As the gingerbread man baked, the old woman waited eagerly, listening to the oven crackle and pop. When the timer dinged, she opened the oven door—and out jumped the gingerbread man!
He landed on the kitchen floor with a little bounce and grinned up at her. "Run, run, as fast as you can!" he cried. "You can't catch me—I'm the Gingerbread Man!"
Before the old woman could even reach for him, he dashed out the open door and into the yard. The old woman chased after him, calling, "Come back, little gingerbread man!
I made you to be my friend!" But the gingerbread man just laughed and ran faster. "Run, run, as fast as you can! You can't catch me—I'm the Gingerbread Man!"
Soon, he passed the old man, who was working in the garden. "Stop, little gingerbread man!" the old man called. "I want to eat you!" But the gingerbread man only ran faster, singing his song.
Next, he ran past a cow grazing in the field. "Moo! Stop, little gingerbread man!" the cow said. "I want to eat you!" But the gingerbread man just laughed and ran on.

Then he passed a horse trotting near the fence. "Neigh! Stop, little gingerbread man!" the horse whinnied. "I want to eat you!" But the gingerbread man only ran faster, singing, "Run, run, as fast as you
can! You can't catch me—I'm the Gingerbread Man!" He ran past a pig rolling in the mud. "Oink! Stop, little gingerbread man!" the pig squealed. "I want to eat you!"
But the gingerbread man just giggled and ran on. Next, he passed a group of farmhands working in the fields. "Hey, little gingerbread man!" they shouted. "Stop! We want to eat you!"
But the gingerbread man only ran faster, singing his song louder than ever. At last, the gingerbread man came to a wide, rushing river. He stopped at the bank, unsure of what to do.
Just then, a sly old fox trotted up beside him. "Good day, little gingerbread man," said the fox with a smooth voice. "Why do you look so worried?"
"I'm trying to cross the river," said the gingerbread man, "but I don't know how to swim!" "Oh, that's no problem," said the fox. "I can carry you across on my back. Just hop on!"
The gingerbread man hesitated. He had outrun everyone else—could he trust the fox? But the fox looked so kind, and the river was so wide. So the gingerbread man climbed onto the fox's back.
The fox waded into the water, and the gingerbread man held on tight. But as they reached the middle of the river, the fox suddenly said, "Little gingerbread man, you're getting heavy.
Jump onto my tail so you don't get wet." The gingerbread man did as he was told. But soon, the fox said, "Little gingerbread man, my tail is sinking! Jump onto my back!"
Again, the gingerbread man obeyed. Then the fox said, "Little gingerbread man, my back is getting tired! Jump onto my nose!"
The gingerbread man, now very nervous, jumped onto the fox's nose. And in the blink of an eye—*CHOMP!*—the fox snapped his jaws shut and gobbled up the gingerbread man in one bite.
And that was the end of the Gingerbread Man. The old woman and the old man were sad when they heard what had happened. They wished they had been able to catch him and keep him safe.
But they also knew that the gingerbread man had been too quick and too clever for his own good. From that day on, the old woman and her husband made sure to keep their doors closed when they
baked gingerbread—just in case.
